clinical_study.brief_title: Obstructive Sleep Apnea Syndrome (OSA) and Getemed
clinical_study.official_title: Diagnostic Characteristics of a Home Polysomnograph for the Diagnosis of Patients With Obstructive Sleep Apnea Syndrome - A Pilot Study

brief_summary.textblock:
It is often clinically impossible to differentiate children with an isolated snoring from those with OSA. The diagnosis of OSA is currently based on nocturnal, laboratory-based polysomnography. This expensive examination is poorly accessible due to appointments delays at hospital.
Our study is designed to compare the characteristics of a home polysomnography versus standard polysomnography for the diagnosis of pediatric OSA.

primary_outcome.measure: Characteristics of a home polysomnograph versus standard polysomnography for the diagnosis of OSA in children.
primary_outcome.description: Standard polysomnography considered pathological if obstructive apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) > 5 / hr. Home polysomnography considered pathological if at least one of the following criteria is present : Respiratory Disturbance Index (RDI) > 10 / hr + /- Desaturation Index > 4% for more than 2.5 / hr. Brouillette index ; pulse wave > 3 desaturation clusters and > 3 desaturation <90%.

secondary_outcome.measure: To determine polygraphic pathological criteria by comparing the RDI per hour of the home polysomnography versus the (AHI) of the standard polysomnography.

arm_group.description: home polysomnography (GETEMED) and standard polysomnography (BRAINNETII) are both carried out in children during 1 night.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male and female subjects, aged 2 to 6 years old, requiring a polysomnography or admitted for intense snoring or suspected sleep apnea
- Parents must have signed the inform consent form and be covered by the National Health Insurance Program.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Parents opposed to the study.
